q.a: it is very important. the reason is: uncertainty can and will strike at any time. songwriting is such an open game, and anything can happen. if you start getting the idea that it is ok to give up, you will probably never get anywhere. the crazy tricks you will invent to overcome uncertainty are what is going to give your songs character. if you are afraid to think like that, then you are not even in the game
q.q: How important is it to finish songs when you have no idea what you are doing?

q.a: clear your mind, and do accurate, timed run throughs! i usually do it with a click. and if i really get stuck, i do a 'door touch' to try to re-set my mind. i walk over to the door and touch the door knob and walk back to my seat and then play the song, all the way through. the more you can re-set your mind, the more accurate picture you will have of the song after doing a full run through. after doing an accurate timed run through, you will start to get a vision of an answer somewhere within the last few seconds of the known song, and it may linger within the first few seconds after you stop. it will start to fade after that. the whole secret is to pay very very close attention in this moment, and try to gather as much info as possible about the situation, (of course you might get lucky and lightening might strike and you might find the whole solution instantly) but try to play process of elimination -- sometimes you might find out you 'definitely don't want another chorus' or you 'definitely want something with the same chords' or you 'definitely want something different' or you 'definitely want something the same' .... try to listen to as many clues as you can find, to narrow it down, ... and then clear your mind and do another run through. don't forget that if you already have 'critical mass' in the song, you are never obligated to do anything more, the only thing you are obligated to do is 'carry the song home', which might even mean ending it sooner than you thought. or it might mean repeating what you have. or it might mean doing something totally different. it's important to stay very open, and again, the only thing that will really produce a reliable solution is clearing your mind, and an accurate, timed run through, and paying very close attention to the moment when you reach the end of the known material. i hope that helps

q.a: the only thing that matters is whether it can tell the difference between a loud and soft note. test it by hitting it hard and see if the note is louder than when you hit it soft. get a keyboard as cheap as you want, but make sure it has this otherwise your whole life will be ruined. (some of the cheap ones don't have it). it is called 'dynamic sensitivity' and if a keyboard doesn't have it, even a perfectly good player will mysteriously sound like a toddler. it's not even fair. it would be like having only one volume for your voice-- you go to whisper in someone's ear, it comes out normal speaking volume. you are being attacked by wolves and you cry for help, and it comes out in a normal speaking volume. this would cripple your ability to express yourself, and the same thing would happen if you had a keyboard without dynamic sensitivity. don't make that mistake. again, you don't have to get an expensive keyboard, you just need to test it to make sure loud and soft notes are a thing
q.q: recommendations for a beginners keyboard?

q.a: anyone who claims to be 'irritated' when a recording is fully in tune with itself, but not tuned to a440, is faking it. this is not irritating, it's just a way to brag about having perfect pitch. even worse, many people who do this are actually wrong about it-- they will tell you the radio is out of tune because they speed up the songs to get more ads in, but that is not true anymore, now they can speed up the songs without changing the pitch, so everything you hear on the radio is in a440, for the most part
q.q: That question about a440 made me curious about an aspect of having perfect pitch (which I do not have)When I hear a note that is sharp or flat relative to its accompaniment it makes me feel very uncomfortable. I find myself straining as though I could correct the pitch with my thoughts alone -- much in the same way I might lean to one side to try to influence an errant bowling ball after it has left my hand.Do you ever get this feeling?  If so, does it only occur for you when the tone is out of tune relative to the musical context?  Or, having perfect pitch, does it also happen for you if the music is in tune with itself, but not with the traditional a440 tuning?

q.a: the reason those "other" composers sound "generic" is because they are doing it as a job. a paid gig. if you are putting a lot of time and effort and care into what you are doing, then a paid situation is only going to drive you crazy. sure, there are 'paid' gigs for people who really care, but they pay WAY more, and you only get those gigs when you reach a more steven spielberg kind of level. these kids who are taking your gigs are working for cheap, and they don't care, and they don't have to care, because they are working for people who can't afford to pay them to care. real care is worth much, much, more than that. in fact, it's priceless. if you care, you need to take a very different approach, and find something else to do for work, and devote your true 'care' to what you really care about. in other words, if you try to sell your babies, you will only be undercut by somebody making cheaper and dumber babies. and that will be so uninspiring that it will ruin your day
q.q: I write music for fun and post it online or whenever I feel like it and have the time. I haven't released much, but the ones I have released I've put a ton of time and effort into. I've gotten a few offers from indie game developers, but always ended up declining due to confidence issues and so composers much younger than me end up getting the job instead. I'll listen to their final product and notice how generic it sounds or how I'm sure I could do better, but when I'm given the opportunity to do it I run away. What is wrong with me?
